content.description:
This might be the best of the three hard sport routes huddled together. Excellent and varied movement on good holds will get you to the fourth bolt. There is a bit of a run out to the 5th bolt, but the holds are good, and the climbing isn't technical. Be aware of the rock quality here. Rest up and dive into the left arcing mini roof to get to good holds before a thin finish. This is a must climb at the grade.

The middle sport route of the three at the right end of the cliff.
6 bolts to Rings

Climb up the dirty gulley into a fun, exposed dihedral.

Near the far left end of the cliff, scramble up a right-angling gully that starts behind a clump of gnarled trees. You can belay at the base of the gully by these trees or rig a gear belay on a ledge a little higher up
Bolted anchor at top with rap rings.

Climb directly up a series of ledges to the top of a large block on your left. Step right to gain the corner and stem and/or face climb your way up to gain a right-angling ramp. Watch for some loose blocks at the top of the corner. [Note: an alternate start is to climb the diagonal hand crack in the large block just to the left (5.8). First climbed by Dan Price in 1990.]

This route climbs the prominent corner in the middle of the face.
Standard rack up to #4 Camalot.

Another classic line at First Face! Climbs the left-angling crack system just right of the large overhangs. At the top of the diagonal crack, traverse right along a narrow ledge to a second left-leaning crackline with a few horizontal features for holds. Follow the crack to a ledge and a bit of a rest on hand jams. Then step left on the ledge to finish up a final three meter thin crack to the top (for this section save some small cams or nuts and try not to take away your finger jams!) Fantastic route.  
  
 [Note: according to Sean Willett's guidebook, "local climbers cleaned this route, but before they could make their first ascent, chalk marks mysteriously appeared up the entire climb. The explanation? Two visiting climbers and former employees of Black Diamond Equipment had been in the area and unknowingly made the first ascent."]

Where the giant arching roofs meet the ground on the climber's right end of the crag.
Standard rack up to #2 Camalot. G-rated gear.

Follow the dihedral up and right (do not move onto the loose block under the overhang on your left) to a small blocky corner. From here move up and left along a sloping ledge past a bolt to join Scrape and Pillage just below the crux exit ramp. [Note: there is another bolt located below and right of the exit ramp which was placed in the early 90s in search of a direct finish for Indian Summer. This finish remains uncompleted.]

Starting below and right of the Scrape and Pillage start, climb up sparsely protected flakes and steps towards a short roof and a right-leaning dihedral.
Mixed

Climb the steep face just right of the white crescent shape and the broken corner. Steep climbing takes you to a rest below a small roof. Move up and left with power to gain a good hold above the roof. Finish up and right to reach the ledge.

Just to the left of the arches at climbers right end of the cliff, there is a boulder with a line of bolts in front of it, leading up to an arching roof feature. That's your line.
Bolts. Two rings for an anchor.

Thin climbing leads up the right facing dihedral and out onto the left face around the third bolt. Continue pulling on small but positive holds to the fifth bolt where you angle right and through a crack, heading for the left facing dihedral under the roof. Pull over the roof at the bolt for full value, or exit right or left for easier climbing. If you go straight up there is an old nut that many choose to use Consider bringing some gear (0.2/1 Camalot) if you prefer some added protection to climb to the belay ledge.

Right most sport route on the cliff.
7 bolts, rings

climbs.name: Professor Diggs and the Berry Bandit

content.description:
Follow bolts up a weakness in pristine smooth rock on great incuts to steeper terrain. Make tenuous moves along incipient cracks before a powerful steeper finish. Well protected and exciting climbing!

Scramble up to high belay of Anniversary Waltzes/Four Minute Smiler, then scurry left for 4m along/behind broken rock to comfortable ledge belay.
Bolts. Rings for anchor.

THE classic First Face climb. This route ascends the prominent roof-capped, left-facing dihedral. Start just right of the base of the dihedral and climb a poorly protected wall (5m, 5.9+) to a large ledge (there is usually a stack of useful cheater stones at the base). Move left and climb the shattered face up to the dihedral (1st crux - protected with small wires and tricams). Jam and layback the dihedral to the roof. Move to the outside corner of the roof and exit up and slightly right on evasive holds (2nd crux). Continue to the top from the ledge or belay/rappel from the anchors for Sins and Transgressions.

Underneath the large overhang, follows the prominent left facing dihedral.
Gear, anchors at top of Sins and Transgressions

Climb past horizontals directly above the belay into a right-leaning feature or traverse right into a corner with a scruffy tree in it and then traverse back left higher up. Follow a series of corners to the left of four successive roofs (avoid these roofs as there are some loose blocks on them), passing one bolt near the top. After the bolt, a committing exit ramp leads to the right and up to the ledges and a fixed piton. Traverse left on ledges to finish.

From the base of Pyramid scramble up and left to belay on a comfortable ledge.
Mixed. Bolt near the top of the successive small roofs.

Fantastic climbing for the bold! The start can be recognized by the pile of cheater stones for those of us who are vertically challenged. To get to the first bolt requires 25 feet of 5.9+ climbing past a ledge. If you bring a .5 or .75 you can place some gear along the way. If you are short then climbing through the first bolt will take some pondering, or a dynamic move. The bolting remains sparse and spicy as you move up a thin finger crack before moving left slightly at the third bolt to a corner (crux). Continue up the corner and into the slight overhang through the fourth bolt. Top out onto the ledge to access the anchor.

Immediately right of the roof capped dihedral of Pyramid.
4 bolts, rings

Easier terrain at the start to gain a ledge. Move to the right facing arrete and find the good holds. This climb is a bit harder to read, but has good holds..

Shares the first half of Westaward Migration. At the ledge, scramble right to the arete. Climb up the arete and onto the face just before reaching the anchors.
7 Bolts to Rings

The tallest line at First Face!  follow five bolts for 25m straight up the face past two distinct and well-protected cruxes before gaining a ledge and angling right up an exposed dihedral for the last 7m (T5.7G) to rings above Indian Summer.

A flat belay areas 10m left of Pyramid (the beautiful left facing dihedral with the roof at the top.
Although listed as a trad line, all the business is over bolts. Gear comes into the equation for a 5.7 right-trending ramp at the top.

Climb to a ledge on easier terrain. From the ledge climb the left most face climb through a crux long move to a good hold before you can celebrate at the rings. The long move can be done as either a deadpoint or a lock-off (look out right for a diagonal crack)

Farthest Route on the left side of First Face. Following the trail at the base of the crag, walk past Anniversary Waltz. Both Westward Migration and Time line share the start and split at the small ledge. At the ledge rock-on into the left corner and continue up the face and small edges on the sharp arete.
8 Bolts to Rings

First Face offers some of the finest climbing in the province, in both sport and traditional styles. Although the climbs are all single pitches, most are a decent length (~25m). And with the added height of the scree slope rising out of Paces Lake, the exposure is delicious. The rock is of unusually fine quality – much friendlier than most of the granite in Nova Scotia – with flat positive holds and decent friction.  
  
 In the off-seasons, the rock catches a fair bit of sun and so tends to be warmer than most other places at these times of year. If there’s no wind the bugs can be bad but if it’s blowing, you can steal a few climbing days here during the peak of bug season. It’s also one of the first cliffs to dry after a rain. 
  
 It is worth noting that with a limited number of easily accessible moderate routes, a beginner party may be more interested in other local crags such as G-Spot, or The Castle. For more information visit  climbnovascotia.ca/crags/
